title: Week 4
text:
TidyTuesday Section
Explore the week’s TidyTuesday challenge. Develop a research question, then answer it through a short data story with effective visualization(s). Provide sufficient background for readers to grasp your narrative.

title: Week 4
text:
Introduction
In this homework, I will explore capital stock distribution by legal nature in micro- and small-enterprises in Brazil. The data is obtained from the TidyTuesday challenge, a weekly challenge for users to explore data cleaning and storytelling! In this case, I’m working with the data correponding to the 4th week of 2026.

title: Week 4
text:
Importing the Data Set

Code## libraries
library(tidyverse)

## Importing the data sets
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2026, week = 4)

companies <- tuesdata$companies
legal_nature <- tuesdata$legal_nature
qualifications <- tuesdata$qualifications
size <- tuesdata$size

title: Week 4
text:
Research Question

What’s the capital stock distribution by legal nature in micro- and small-enterprises in Brazil?

title: Week 4
text:
Data Cleaning
I begin by loading the necessary libraries and importing the relevant datasets from the TidyTuesday repository. The primary dataset used in this analysis is companies, which contains information on firm size, legal nature, and declared capital stock.

Code## exploring the data
glimpse(companies)

Rows: 141,332
Columns: 6
$ company_id          <dbl> 41273639, 41274138, 41274505, 41274745, 41274856, …
$ company_name        <chr> "MH MATERIAIS DE CONSTRUCAO LTDA", "CLINICA ESTETI…
$ legal_nature        <chr> "Limited Liability Business Company (LLC)", "Limit…
$ owner_qualification <chr> "Managing Partner / Partner-Administrator", "Manag…
$ capital_stock       <dbl> 1000000, 200000, 500000, 159600, 200000, 300000, 1…
$ company_size        <chr> "small-enterprise", "micro-enterprise", "small-ent…

Codecompanies |>
  group_by(company_size) |>
  count()

# A tibble: 3 × 2
# Groups:   company_size [3]
  company_size         n
  <chr>            <int>
1 micro-enterprise 66202
2 other            42520
3 small-enterprise 32610

Code## keep only the micro enterprises
companies_micro <- companies |>
  filter(company_size == "micro-enterprise")

#counting
companies_micro |>
  count(legal_nature) |>
  arrange(desc(n))

# A tibble: 9 × 2
  legal_nature                                        n
  <chr>                                           <int>
1 Limited Liability Business Company (LLC)        51591
2 Sole Proprietorship                             14162
3 Simple Limited Partnership                        155
4 Simple Innovation Company                         144
5 Individual Limited Liability Company (Business)   108
6 Sole Member Law Firm                               22
7 Simple Partnership (Pure)                          14
8 General Partnership                                 3
9 Privately Held Corporation                          3

Code# In Millions to avoid scientific notation
companies_micro <- companies_micro |> 
  mutate(capital_stock_m = capital_stock/1000000) |> 
  filter(capital_stock_m < 1000) # remove obvious far out value

# In Millions to avoid scientific notation
companies <- companies |> 
  mutate(capital_stock_m = capital_stock/1000000)



Code#bar plot mean
companies_micro |>
  group_by(legal_nature) |>
  summarise(mean_capital_m = mean(capital_stock_m)) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(legal_nature, mean_capital_m), y = mean_capital_m)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Mean Capital Stock per Micro-Enterprise",
    x = "Legal Nature",
    y = "Mean Capital Stock (Million BRL)")






Code#bar plot median to see if any outliers remain / far out values
companies_micro |>
  group_by(legal_nature) |>
  summarise(median_capital_m = median(capital_stock_m)) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(legal_nature, median_capital_m), y = median_capital_m)) +
  geom_col() +
  scale_fill_viridis_d() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Median Capital Stock per Micro-Enterprise",
    x = "Legal Nature",
    y = "Mean Capital Stock (Million BRL)")








Codecompanies |>
  mutate(capital_stock_m = capital_stock / 1000000) |>
  filter(capital_stock_m < 1,
    company_size %in% c("micro-enterprise", "small-enterprise")) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = legal_nature, y = capital_stock_m, fill = legal_nature)) +
  geom_boxplot()+
  scale_color_viridis_d() +
  facet_wrap(~ company_size) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal() +
    theme(legend.position = "none")+
  labs(
    title = "Capital Stock Distribution by Legal Nature in Brazilian Enterprises",
    x = "Legal Nature",
    y = "Capital Stock (Million BRL)",
    caption = "Source: TidyTuesday Challenge Week 4, 2026. Author: David Rios") +
    theme(plot.title.position = "plot")



Fig. 1: Capital stock distribution by legal nature among Brazilian micro- and small enterprises.

title: Week 4
text:
Conclusions
To understand how capital stock varies by legal nature among micro-enterprises, I first examined both mean and median capital stock values. Comparing these two measures helps assess the influence of remaining outliers and skewness in the data.
Fig. 1 reveals the differences in how capital stock is distributed across legal forms for both micro- and small enterprises in Brazil. Even after restricting the study to firms with less than 1 million BRL in capital, given the amount of outliers, the spread and tendency of capital stock vary a lot by legal nature. Note that this study assumes that both micro- and small-enterprises reports their capital stock consciously.
For micro-enterprises, most legal forms are located at low levels of declared capital. But there some enterprises that contradicts this. For example, Limited Liability Business Companies (LLCs) and Individual Limited Liability Companies display wider spreads and more outliers, suggesting that these structures are associated with firms that declare more capital even within the smallest size category. This would be an interesting study to pursue further with more time.
Among small enterprises, these differences become more obvious. Legal forms such as LLCs and Simple Limited Partnerships have higher medians and greater variability, while simpler structures remain concentrated at lower capital levels. This pattern indicates that whenever enterprises grow, the choice of legal nature becomes more strongly associated with how much capital they report.
One challenge I had during this project was dealing with outliers. I decided to limit the study to those firms with less than 1 million BRL in capital, but I do recognize this is not the best way to go about it. Future studies should look at it from a proportion perspectives comparing to their median value in each legal category. Another possibility could be using a logarithmic transformation to emphasize proportional differences rather than absolute values on the capital stock variable.
Overall, our last visualization shows that legal nature is not just a formal label but carries information about the financial structure and scale of Brazilian enterprises. Even within the micro- and small-enterprise categories, organizational form is closely related to how much capital a firm declares.

title: Week 6
text:
Introduction
In this TT challenge, I will be exploring the data set about the winter olympics. The 2026 Winter Olympics is happening at Milan-Cortina, Italy. The dataset contains detailed information about all 1,866 Olympic events, including both competition and training sessions across various winter sport disciplines.
…

title: Week 6
text:
Importing the Data Set

Code## libraries
library(tidyverse)

## Importing the data sets
olympics <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2026/2026-02-10/schedule.csv')

title: Week 6
text:
Research Question

Which days of the week host the most medal events at the 2026 Winter Olympics, and how do these events distribute across different sport disciplines?

title: Week 6
text:
Data Cleaning
I first prepare the data set which I will use later on. There is a lot of variables, and I am only keeping those who directly answer my research question.

Code## exploring the data
# glimpse(olympics)

olympics_clean <- olympics |> 
  select(date, discipline_name, event_description, is_medal_event, venue_name, day_of_week)

# Summarize medal events by day of week
medal_summary <- olympics_clean %>% 
  group_by(day_of_week, is_medal_event) %>% 
  summarise(count = n(), .groups = 'drop') %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = is_medal_event, values_from = count, values_fill = 0) %>% 
  rename(medal_events = `TRUE`, non_medal_events = `FALSE`) %>% 
  mutate( total_events = medal_events + non_medal_events,
    medal_percentage = (medal_events / total_events) * 100,
    day_order = factor(day_of_week, levels = c("Monday", "Tuesday", "Wednesday", 
                                                 "Thursday", "Friday", "Saturday", "Sunday"))) %>% 
  arrange(day_order)



Codemedal_summary %>% 
  arrange(desc(medal_events)) %>% 
  select(day_of_week, medal_events, non_medal_events, total_events, medal_percentage) %>% 
  mutate(medal_percentage = round(medal_percentage, 1))

# A tibble: 7 × 5
  day_of_week medal_events non_medal_events total_events medal_percentage
  <chr>              <int>            <int>        <int>            <dbl>
1 Saturday              57              230          287             19.9
2 Sunday                55              220          275             20  
3 Friday                52              246          298             17.4
4 Wednesday             48              218          266             18  
5 Thursday              45              219          264             17  
6 Monday                44              206          250             17.6
7 Tuesday               43              183          226             19  



Codemedal_summary %>% 
  ggplot(aes(
    x = fct_reorder(day_order, medal_events),
    y = medal_events,
    fill = medal_events)) +
  geom_col() +
  scale_fill_viridis_c("Medal Events") +
  labs(title = "Medal Events by Day of the Week",
       subtitle = "2026 Winter Olympics",
    x = NULL,
    y = "Number of Medal Events",
    caption = "Source: TidyTuesday Challenge Week 6, 2026. Author: David Rios") +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal() 



Fig. 1: We see how Saturday is the day with more medals events




Codeolympics|> 
  filter(is_medal_event) |>  
  count(day_of_week, discipline_name) |> 
  ggplot(aes(
    x = day_of_week,
    y = fct_reorder(discipline_name, n, sum),
    fill = n)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_viridis_c("Medal Events") +
  labs(title = "Medal Events by Day and Sport Discipline",
       subtitle = "2026 Winter Olympics",
       x = NULL,
       y = NULL, 
    caption = "Source: TidyTuesday Challenge Week 6, 2026. Author: David Rios") +
  theme_minimal()



Fig. 2: We see that Freestyle Skiins and Speed Skating has the higher amount of Medal Events

title: Week 6
text:
Conclusions
In this TT challenge, I found out two things:

Saturday dominates medal events.
Sport-specific distribution patterns are evident.

The heatmap shows that Freestyle Skiing has the highest concentration of medal events. From prior knowledge, there was significant attention and anticipation surrounding the competition between the U.S. and Japan in this discipline. Ultimately, the Japanese team won the gold medal, while the U.S. team earned silver.

It’s worth noting that some sports have not yet occurred, which directly affects our interpretation of the plot.

Despite this, we can observe interesting temporal patterns and strategic insights from the 2026 Winter Olympics schedule:

Friday serves as a “pre-weekend peak” with high medal event concentration, particularly in Freestyle Skiing, creating momentum leading into the weekend
Thursday represents a mid-week surge, possibly timed to maintain audience engagement between the weekend peaks
Sunday maintains strong medal activity, ensuring the week ends on a high note before the Monday reset

Overall, the 2026 Winter Olympics schedule demonstrates careful planning: Saturday serves as the apex for medal events, while the distribution across disciplines highlights sports prominence, with Freestyle Skiing and Speed Skating leading the way. At the same time, the temporal patterns balance weekend viewership peaks with consistent daily engagement across the Games.

text: Intro to Data Science Review!

title: Pre-Class Learning Summaries
text:
Advanced Spatial Visualization
We pretend the Earth is an ellipsoid, but there is a lot of disagreement when plotting the world map. The U.S. has a metric system surprisingly!
Ellipsoid: shape of the earth
Datum: where the ellipsoid goes
Projection: how to flatten 2D or 3D
CRS = Datum + Ellipsoid

Why do we use many different local CRSs rather than just one CRS for the whole earth?


Accuracy and Precision. The ellipsoid model doesn’t fit perfectly, so we adjust the model and datum for each small region.


Why do we care about Coordinate Reference System?


Different datasets may use different CRSs. If these CRSs are not accounted for, the spatial points/regions will not align correctly on a map.
Different CRSs may use different units (e.g., meters, feet). Consistency in units is essential for accurate distance and area calculations.
Joining datasets from multiple sources requires a common CRS.

title: Pre-Class Learning Summaries
text:
Structure Data. Types: Revisited

list: most common one. Could be name and unnamed when referring to the elements in this list.

vector: name and unammed
dataframe:named list. All the columns have a name.

tibble: a special type of data frame
sf: it has a geometry column.

title: Pre-Class Learning Summaries
text:
Visualizing Spatial Data

Get the spatial data, usually by obtaining a shapefile and read using sf::st_read or “USAboundaries”
Joint other data. Important: Make sure both are in the same CRS, if not use sf::st_crs & sf::st_transform.
Plot sf::geom_sf

title: Cleaning SFO Weather Data
text:
Exercise
Carryout the following steps to clean and save the San Francisco Weather data. Make sure to download and add the data file to your portfolio repository as instructed.

title: Cleaning SFO Weather Data
text:
Read in the weather data in this file with the correct relative file path after you move it to the instructed location.
There is a variable that has values that don’t make sense in the data context. Figure out which variable this is and clean it up by making those values missing using na_if().
Create a variable called dateInYear that indicates the day of the year (1-365) for each case. (Jan 1 should be 1, and Dec 31 should be 365).
Create a variable called month_name that shows the 3-letter abbreviation for each case.
Save the wrangled data to the data/processed/ folder using write_csv(). Name this file weather_clean.csv. Look up the documentation for this function by typing ?write_csv in the Console. You’ll need to write an appropriate relative path.
